page.title: 01Scanning Our Block
page.content: The only village of some size is Shipham, which means place or enclosure for sheep. Many of Shipham's fields are used for sheep grazing. Shipham is set in so quiet a hollow of the Mendips that it is difficult to believe that about one hundred and fifty years ago it had the reputation of being the toughest of all mining villages in the landscape. The lead mining and digging for calamine has long since ceased; today the chief occupation after farming is probably quarrying. A mile beyond Shipham there are two large limestone quarries, but they are just outside our block. We experience the trundling Quarry lorries travelling through Shipham. Around Shipham are patches of "gruffy ground", caused by mine shafts, now an ideal place for rabbits and sheep .
